title: King Of Change proves he is no fluke with Queen Elizabeth victory on Champions Day
text:
When King Of Change was second in the 2,000 Guineas at 66-1 in May, many assumed it was a fluke but he proved it was no such thing on Saturday when he won the £1,100,000 Queen Elizabeth II Stakes, the highlight of Qipco British Champions Day.

The mud at Ascot even proved too much for Stradivarius as more equine stars were buried in it than born out of it but King Of Change proved the exception when the 12-1 shot powered through the race for Sean Levey to beat the French-trained second favourite, The Revenant, a length and a quarter.

Even for big yards the outcome of one race can be season-changing and though it was Richard Hannon’s 144th of the year, it was a result, the trainer said, that would “shorten the winter”.

This season, the mile division has lacked a standout horse but Hannon now has the ace miler for next year and the trainer joked that he would be going home to lasso the yearling half-sister to make absolutely sure she followed him to the yard.

“People thought I was a bit petulant after the 2,000 Guineas for not celebrating being second but we’ve always thought the world of this horse and to be second in the Guineas is a great run, but you don’t remember those,” he said. “Now he’ll be remembered.”
